Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives
Women's Funding Coalition Records TAM 281
0.75 Linear Feet (2 boxes)
1982-1987 1-2
Conditions Governing Access
Materials are open without restrictions.
Immediate Source of Acquisition
Materials found in collection; provenance is unknown. The accession number associated with this collection is 1950.054.
Arrangement
This collection has not been arranged by an archivist. Materials are in the order in which they were received from the donor.
Historical/Biographical Note
The Women's Funding Coalition (WFC), envisioned as a "United Way" to fund women's organizations through payroll deductions, and representing over thirty community and women's organizations in New York City, was established in 1981, and appears to have been in existence throughout the 1980s. The task of identifying likely employers that would participate in this scheme appears to have occupied the bulk of the WFC's energies, although a few projects were undertaken, including one apparently not represented in this collection, Project Open Doors (funded by New York's Department of Employment), through which hundreds of low-income women were placed in apprenticeship positions with the participating organizations which included women's shelters, health clinics, rape crisis centers, and other community agencies. The donor of these records, Connie Kopelov (b. 1926), represented the Coalition of Labor Union Women on the board of the WFC.
Preferred Citation
Identification of item, date; Women's Funding Coalition Records; TAM 281; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.
Processing Information
About half of the materials were originally unfoldered, and are now in four folders labeled "Records, Miscellaneous".
Related Material at the Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives
Connie Kopelov Papers (TAG 064)
Scope and Content Note
This small collection contains minutes, planning documents, reports, and by-laws; correspondence with other women's organizations, including the National Network of Women's Funds, and with various charities and government agencies; and printed ephemera, including fliers and circulars announcing WFC activities and events. There is a file relating to a Walkathon, and another relating to an "Innovators for Women$hare" benefit.
